questions.question: If cleared for take-off immediately following the very low approach and overshoot of a large aircraft, the pilot should

answers.1: take off immediately otherwise the trailing vortices will descend into the flight path.
answers.2: taxi to position on the runway and wait until it is considered safe to take off.
answers.3: decline take-off clearance and inform ATC of the reason for non-acceptance.
answers.4: wait for 2 minutes after the large aircraft has passed then take off.

references: TC AIM-RAC - ATC Clearances, Instructions and Information
Flight Training Manual Chapter 16 - Take-Off

questions.question: The controller offers the option for a take-off from a runway intersection. The pilot must be aware that

answers.1: the remaining runway length will not be stated by the controller.
answers.2: it is the pilot’s responsibility to ensure that the remaining runway length is sufficient for take-off.
answers.3: the controller will ensure that the remaining runway length is sufficient for take-off.
answers.4: noise abatement procedures have been cancelled.

references: TC AIM-RAC - Take-off Clearance
CARs 602.96 - Operations at or in the Vicinity of an Aerodrome - General

questions.question: A pilot requests an intersection take-off from ATC. If authorized,

answers.1: the controller will always give the remaining runway length.
answers.2: the controller will ensure that the remaining runway length is sufficient for take-off.
answers.3: it is the pilot’s responsibility to ensure that the remaining runway length is sufficient for take-off.
answers.4: any noise abatement procedures for the runway are automatically cancelled.

references: TC AIM-RAC - Take-off Clearance
CARs 602.96 - Operations at or in the Vicinity of an Aerodrome - General

questions.question: When an arriving aircraft is cleared “to the circuit”, the pilot should interpret this to mean join the circuit

answers.1: on the downwind leg at circuit height.
answers.2: from the upwind side of the runway in all cases.
answers.3: on base leg if convenient.
answers.4: on final for a straight in approach.

references: TC AIM-RAC - Initial Clearance

questions.question: When a NORDO aircraft crosses an airport for the purpose of obtaining landing information it should maintain

answers.1: circuit height.
answers.2: 1,000 feet above circuit height.
answers.3: at least 2,000 feet AGL.
answers.4: at least 500 feet above circuit height.

references: TC AIM-RAC - Arrival Procedures - NORDO Aircraft

questions.question: An aircraft is “cleared to the circuit” where a left hand circuit is in effect. Without further approval from ATC a right turn may be made to

answers.1: join the final leg.
answers.2: join the base leg.
answers.3: join cross-wind or a partial right turn to join the downwind leg.
answers.4: descend on the downwind leg.

references: TC AIM-RAC - Initial Clearance

questions.question: When instructed to continue an approach to a runway which is clear of traffic, what action should the pilot take if no landing clearance is received?

answers.1: Circle 360° to the left.
answers.2: Circle 360° in the direction of the circuit.
answers.3: Complete the landing.
answers.4: Request landing clearance.

references: TC AIM-RAC - Landing Clearance

questions.question: A NOTAM has been published for an airport, which is 400 feet ASL, stating the circuit height is 1,500 feet ASL. When the ceiling is 1,000 overcast and the visibility is 3 miles, the circuit height in controlled airspace should be

answers.1: 500 feet below the cloud base.
answers.2: 1,500 feet ASL.
answers.3: 1,100 feet above the airport elevation.
answers.4: 1,000 feet above the airport elevation

references: CARs 602.114 - Minimum Visual Meteorological Conditions for VFR Flight

questions.question: When the reported ceiling is 1,000 feet overcast and visibility is 3 miles, to remain VFR, an aircraft cleared to the circuit must join

answers.1: as high as possible without entering cloud.
answers.2: at 500 feet below cloud base.
answers.3: at 700 feet AGL.
answers.4: in accordance with Special VFR.

references: CARs 602.114 - Minimum Visual Meteorological Conditions for VFR Flight

questions.question: Aircraft flying VFR normally join the circuit at 1,000 feet AAE. This may not always be possible because of

answers.1: the possibility of a “straight in” clearance to the airport in which case the final leg would normally be entered at less than 1,000 feet.
answers.2: the existence of a NOTAM which provides for a different circuit altitude.
answers.3: weather conditions which may necessitate a circuit height lower than 1,000 feet.
answers.4: the existence of any of the above circumstances.

references: TC AIM-RAC - Traffic Circuits - Controlled Airports

questions.question: A pilot on final approach is requested by ATC to reduce airspeed. The pilot should

answers.1: comply, giving due consideration to safe minimum manoeuvering speed of the aircraft.
answers.2: acknowledge transmission and execute a 360° turn.
answers.3: overshoot and rejoin the circuit.
answers.4: reduce airspeed well below normal approach speed range.

references: TC AIM-RAC - ATC Clearances, Instructions and Information
TC AIM-RAC - Speed Adjustment - Radar Controlled Aircraft
CARs 602.31 - Compliance with Air Traffic Control Instructions and Clearances

questions.question: A pilot is cleared to land but is concerned about the high cross-wind component. The pilot should

answers.1: use full flaps and approach at a reduced speed.
answers.2: alter heading and land on another runway which is more into wind.
answers.3: overshoot and request an into-wind runway.
answers.4: continue the approach and land as the clearance must be obeyed.

references: TC AIM-RAC - Preferential Runway Assignment
CARs 602.31 - Compliance with Air Traffic Control Instructions and Clearances

questions.question: A pilot on a VFR flight is being vectored by ATC towards an extensive unbroken layer of cloud. The responsibility for remaining VFR rests with

answers.1: the radar operator.
answers.2: ATC since the flight is designated VFR.
answers.3: ATC since the cloud is visible on radar.
answers.4: the pilot.

references: TC AIM-RAC - Radar Navigation Assistance To VFR Flights

questions.question: A student pilot on a VFR flight has been given a radar vector by ATC. Ahead, at a lower altitude, is a solid overcast cloud condition. The pilot should

answers.1: climb above the cloud and fly “VFR over the top”.
answers.2: alter heading as necessary to remain VFR and advise ATC.
answers.3: maintain heading and altitude as it is an ATC clearance.
answers.4: maintain heading and altitude because ATC knows of the cloud and will issue further instructions.

references: TC AIM-RAC - Radar Navigation Assistance To VFR Flights

questions.question: An aircraft on a Special VFR flight has been cleared for a “straight in” approach. Because of low ceiling and poor visibility, the pilot is concerned about the exact location of a radio mast in the vicinity. Avoiding this obstruction is the responsibility

answers.1: of the pilot.
answers.2: of the tower controller as the controller is aware of the obstruction.
answers.3: of ATC as the pilot has been given Special VFR clearance.
answers.4: shared equally by the pilot and the controller.

references: TC AIM-RAC - ATC Clearances, Instructions and Information

questions.question: A pilot on a Special VFR flight has been cleared to the circuit. Ahead, at a lower altitude, is a solid layer of stratus cloud. Remaining clear of cloud is the responsibility of

answers.1: the tower controller as it is within a Control Zone.
answers.2: ATC because the weather is below VFR.
answers.3: the pilot and ATC.
answers.4: the pilot.

references: TC AIM-RAC - ATC Clearances, Instructions and Information
TC AIM-RAC - Control Zones

questions.question: A pilot on a VFR flight in Class C airspace is advised by ATC to maintain a specific heading. In the pilot’s opinion, this heading will cause conflict with another aircraft. The pilot should

answers.1: always change altitude as required to avoid the other aircraft.
answers.2: maintain the specified heading to comply with the CARs.
answers.3: alter heading to avoid the other aircraft and advise ATC.
answers.4: maintain the specified heading as separation will be provided by the controller.

references: TC AIM-RAC - ATC Clearances, Instructions and Information
CARs 602.19 - Right of Way - General

questions.question: Unless ATC instructs otherwise, pilots operating VFR shall select transponder code 1200 when flying at or below ..... feet ASL and code ..... when flying above that altitude.
references: TC AIM-COM - VFR Operations

questions.question: Pilots shall activate the transponder “ident” feature

answers.1: before entering control zones.
answers.2: only when so instructed by ATC.
answers.3: before every change of altitude.
answers.4: after every change of an assigned code.

references: TC AIM-COM - Phraseology

questions.question: The holder of a student pilot permit may for the sole purpose of the holder’s own flight training act as PIC of an aircraft

answers.1: only when accompanied by a flight instructor.
answers.2: by day and night and authorized by a supervising flight instructor.
answers.3: by day only and authorized by a supervising flight instructor.
answers.4: while carrying passengers.

references: CARs 401.19 - Student Pilot Permits - Privileges

questions.question: The PIC of an aircraft shall comply with any light signals or ground marking prescribed in the CARs

answers.1: only while in class C airspace if they are part of an ATC clearance.
answers.2: only while in a Control Zone if they are part of an ATC instruction.
answers.3: at all times.
answers.4: at all times provided safety is not jeopardized.

references: TC AIM-RAC - ATC Clearances, Instructions and Information
CARs 602.31 - Compliance with Air Traffic Control Instructions and Clearances

questions.question: Before setting out on any VFR flight, a pilot is required to

answers.1: read all weather reports received from stations within 100 miles of destination.
answers.2: file a flight itinerary.
answers.3: be familiar with all available information appropriate to the flight.
answers.4: obtain an ATC clearance.

references: CARs 602.71 - Pre-flight Information

questions.question: Terminal airspace dimensions and VHF sector frequencies for certain high density traffic airports in Canada are shown

answers.1: in the Designated Airspace Handbook and the TC AIM.
answers.2: on the VTA chart and in the CFS.
answers.3: on the VTA and VNC charts.
answers.4: in the CFS and on the VNC chart.

references: TC AIM-MAP - VFR Aeronautical Information
